posts.cooked: I suggest moving the repository from github.com to codeberg.org, as a more suitable home for an open source project.

link_counts.title: GitHub: Let‚Äôs build from here ¬∑ GitHub

posts.cooked: What makes it more suitable for open source projects? GitHub is used by many open source projects and is very suitable.

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked: This organization has been around for two years. Will they be around in 5? 10? If I ran Signal, I would not risk a complete outage of my service if this organization suddenly goes under. GitHub is proven and owned by a company that‚Äôs been around for 40 years. It sucks that that company is Microsoft, but in making decisions there‚Äôs being idealistic, and then there‚Äôs surviving. Signal probably prefers survival over idealism.

I dislike github as well, but share the concerns about codeberg being around long term. If they were to move the repo at all I would imagine it would move to gitlab, it‚Äôs a more established alternative.

posts.name: Alexia
posts.cooked:
It‚Äôs been another year; GitHub and GitLab are both leaning more and more into AI which Signal fundamentally does not align with;

It‚Äôs probably a good idea to consider a move off of GitHub; Not because Open-Source projects can‚Äôt exist there, but because there are concerns to be had about their use of code hosted on their platform to train Copilot and the various companies they collaborate with (i.e OpenAI)

I‚Äôm not sure if Codeberg is the right way to go here, simply because Codeberg doesn‚Äôt exactly have the most powerful hardware to tank such a massive project moving over; There would have to be coordination between Codeberg e.V and Signal to make sure things don‚Äôt break, probably some server upgrades first

That said, Forgejo as a piece of software is pretty damn efficient and Signal might be able to self-host it, although that obviously involves some logistics in setting that up and moving things over, moreso than just moving to another platform

I can sort of understand the perspective of staying on GitHub for the sake of not disrupting the flow of things too, but I definitely still want to push for a change being made here.

TGRush:

It‚Äôs probably a good idea to consider a move off of GitHub; Not because Open-Source projects can‚Äôt exist there, but because there are concerns to be had about their use of code hosted on their platform to train Copilot and the various companies they collaborate with (i.e OpenAI)

So? Unless this violates the licencing terms of the Signal source code that shouldn‚Äôt be a problem, right?

It should prove to be fun if it forces an LLM to be released under the AGPL v3 Terms because it‚Äôs partly derived from Signal‚Äôs source code.

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked: Yeah like I said six months ago, there is no reason to make such a risky move other than idealism, and idealism doesn‚Äôt pay salaries. If something went wrong and the service went completely down, it would cause massive reputation damage.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
i don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs just a matter of idealism, it‚Äôs also a matter of GitHub explicitly becoming part of Microsoft‚Äôs AI product.

TechRadar ‚Äì 12 Aug 25

GitHub CEO resigns - is this the latest sign of its Microsoft absorption?

Thomas Dohmke is leaving GitHub

i don‚Äôt think codeberg is going down soon, but talking about reputational damage, isn‚Äôt there a reputational damage from still using GitHub?

TeeJay82:

So? Unless this violates the licencing terms of the Signal source code that shouldn‚Äôt be a problem, right?

i don‚Äôt know if you‚Äôve taken a look at what the AI landscape looks like right now, but it‚Äôs all about violating licenses. Copilot is proprietary, and AI companies are arguing in court that piracy is fine (for them, not for you and me) because they only way they know how to make a profit is by pirating

rassilon1963:

isn‚Äôt there a reputational damage from still using GitHub?

Not as big as a service outage for ~100M people, most of which probably don‚Äôt know or care what GitHub is.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
you‚Äôre either assuming or unknowingly implying that a. that is likely, b. it will last long enough to actually affect Signal users and not just make a bad day for signal devs, c. that it‚Äôll be as bad as the Signal servers going down.
for the question of stability, even curl is preparing the groundwork for the world in which they need to abandon GitHub

Mastodon ‚Äì 12 Aug 25

daniel:// stenberg:// (@bagder@mastodon.social)

You can now try out the #curl git mirror on @Codeberg@social.anoxinon.de: https://codeberg.org/curl/curl-mirror Consider it a test pilot for now. We won't do PRs and issues there so there's an obvious risk this will just be too messy...

and that‚Äôs after saying the reason they‚Äôre still on GitHub isn‚Äôt because it‚Äôs supperior, but because GitHub gives them money.

Mastodon ‚Äì 8 Aug 25

daniel:// stenberg:// (@bagder@mastodon.social)

it is curious how many people feel they need to ask me why #curl is not moving off #GitHub The cold and boring answer is money. GitHub sponsors us with a crapload of CI infra that there is no other company even close to doing. So while they may be...

correct my if i‚Äôm wrong, but Microsoft‚Äôs AI division isn‚Äôt funding Signal, hence they don‚Äôt have the same considerations that curl have.

i agree calling GitHub an absolute disgrace is dishonest, it‚Äôs not a disaster to stay there, just a bad look. but to pretend Codeberg is vaporware that‚Äôs gonna vanish any day now is also extremely disingenuous.

posts.cooked:
rassilon1963:

i don‚Äôt know if you‚Äôve taken a look at what the AI landscape looks like right now, but it‚Äôs all about violating licenses. Copilot is proprietary, and AI companies are arguing in court that piracy is fine (for them, not for you and me) because they only way they know how to make a profit is by pirating

Hm, wouldn‚Äôt that have implications in a common law system? If those companies set a moral standard they shouldn‚Äôt be surprised if the masses follow their example.

But of course, one law for the lion and the ox is oppression, so who am I kidding‚Ä¶

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked: you‚Äôre assuming the court system works in a rational way and isn‚Äôt influenced by the interests of large companies. Anthropic was ruled to have the right to train AI for books they paid for (i.e. reproduce them, since AI memorises and can spit out those books), meanwhile the Internet Archive was not allowed to digitise books they paid for and lend them 1:1 such that every time they lent out a digital copy they made the physical one unavailable.
